column10: Philip and Sarah Moss have run Filligan’s, one of the most distinctive and creative artisan food businesses in Ireland, for almost twenty years now. Filligan’s Preserves are available locally in good B&Bs and shops, and they just have to be on your shopping list. Filligans preserves are stocked in the Craft Gallery, Glenties, Morgan’s, Portnoo and Bonners, Ardara.

column7: Rick Le Vert and Libby Carton
column10: There are five beers in the Kinnegar stable: Limeburner, a pale ale; Rustbucket, a rye ale; Yannaroddy, their porter; Scraggy Bay, an India pale ale; and Devil’s Backbone, an amber ale. The Kinnegar beers are the perfect place to start the exuberant exploration of WAW craft brews. Brewery tours are available by prior arrangement on Saturdays between 12 and 3pm. Book on 074 915 8874.

If you are in the region on a Saturday morning then don’t, whatever you do, miss the Ramelton Country Market. Legendary for its traybakes, breads, vegetarian foods, preserves, home-grown veg and festive goods. Get your elbows ready for the approach, as the cord drops and all the shoppers descend.
Here is the place to find everything you need if you are preparing a picnic for the journey, and great for self-catering.

Genuinely slow-cooked breads from a wood-fired pizza oven. You can find them in the Tap Room, Rathmullan; Harry’s, Bridgend (ncluding the Saturday market); The Counter, Letterkenny and other outlets. The bakery is not open to the public at this time but you are welcome to visit by appointment.
There’s a gentle walk up to the striking Glenevin waterfall, while the 15k Mamore Gap Walk along the ridge of the Urris Hills is one of the best hill walks in Ireland.
Extremely well run adventure school, offering courses for all levels, led by Adrian Harkin.

Derry’s famous 17th century landmark is a centre for social, political and cultural events. There are two brilliant cafés associated with the Guildhall – Guild, which is housed in the riverside entrance to the building, and Legenderry Warehouse No 1, which is adjacent to the main building. Guild opens onto the riverside selling snacks and drinks prepared by much-loved Bundoran restaurant The Beach House. Legenderry Warehouse is great for brunch and is proud of it’s wonderful coffee. It also sports a very funky shop with very smart goods to bring home from the maiden city.

Legenderry Warehouse No 1, Guildhall Street, Derry
+ 44 2871 264798 www.legenderrywarehouseno1.com

Guild, The Guildhall, Derry + 44 2871 360505
www.guildcafe.co.uk
Have a 45 minute bike ride with Cycle Inishowen and learn the wildlife, geology and history.
Ballyliffin boasts two of the most famous links golf courses in the country.
4,000 year old stone fort mapped by Ptolemy in 2nd-century BC, atop this dominant hill overlooking all of County Donegal.
Drive the 72km circuit drive travelling along the Knockalla Coast Road and don’t miss the view to Portsalon and Ballymastocker Bay
Narosa is an ISA approved surf school on Killahoey Beach, offering horse riding, kids camps, surf fit classes, guided walks and other beach-side activities.
